course.subject: MATH
course.name: Introduction to Multivariable Calculus
course.description: Differentiation in several variables, with applications in approximation, maximum and minimum and geometry. Integration in several variables, vector analysis.
course.prerequisites: A passing grade in AL Pure Mathematics / AL Applied Mathematics; OR MATH 1014; OR MATH 1020; OR MATH 1024

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: (WARNING: VERY LONG REVIEW) Useful content but Extremely disappointing arrangement
reviews.comment_content:
Contents include (For more details, please read others' post):
Coordinate systems
Plane and line equations
Parametric equations
Vectors, dot and cross product

Multivariable Limits
Partial Differentiation
Gradient vector
Extreme values
Iterated (double/triple) integral

Vector fields and work
Line integral
Green's Theorem

These are basically practical and necessary for most engineering students.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TL;DR: He put a lot of effort into teaching. However, if you want a fair grading scheme and stable exam arrangement, avoid him at all cost.

Fair to say, I must admit that he put a lot of effort into teaching. He makes handwritten notes. The concept explaining is fine.

You may want to ask why I still give E on teaching anyway if he teaches well? The answer is the exam arrangements. For those who don't know what happened, long story short, due to some students faced technical issues with the platform used in the midterm, WeBWorK, the midterm is CANCELLED, while the final exam arrangement is simply unfair.

Below is what happened to the midterm in details:
The main reason leading to the midterm being cancelled is because if students do not perform any preview/grade test in the WeBWorK, the system will assume the student is idling and log out automatically after 30 minutes.

Some students were like speedrunning the midterm for more than 30 minutes without checking the answer. When they submit the answers, the system logged out so their answers are gone. However, Prof. Qian did NOT inform us about this earlier. More than 20% of students were affected (He said he correctly received the answers from 80% of the students, but some of them actually faced this problem also. Though they had enough time to rewrite all the answers and submit.)

After informed about this issue, Prof. Qian announced that the midterm is cancelled. And he told the student who took the midterm "just treat it as an EXERCISE", and state that the grade weight will be shifted to the final, "having 90% final is NORMAL". WHAT? Professor, do you think our time spent studying the midterm of this course is a joke?

On the night after the midterm, Prof. Qian and the TAs finally come up with the decision that the midterm is considered valid and a makeup midterm will be arranged, but at last, since some student think this solution is not fair for all students, it is announced again cancelled the next day, with a more reasonable Homework 30%/Final 70% weighting.

I am extremely dissatisfied with the arrangement. Judging from how he told us to treat the midterm as an exercise, I feel that he is irresponsible on this issue. He is supposed to be responsible for knowing the potential technical problems that will be faced by students, especially with the fact that WeBWorK has been adapted for a long time in HKUST. But no, he did not tell us about this problem.


And now, for the final:
The arrangement of the final is a total disaster. It is basically the mix of all inconvenience and panic. In contrast to the midterm, they completely banned calculators and formula sheet in the final exam. It also required us to use a scanner app to scan our answers.

And you know what? They made this twice as inconvenient by forcing us to use the scanner app on another device (This means you have to bring 3 devices into the exam, one for viewing questions, one for Zoom and one for scanning), and not providing any alternatives in case we don’t have or can’t borrow the third device from anyone, while a laptop and a mobile phone should be enough for such kind of exam.
(Some may argue that he provided us with a way to use the only laptop and mobile phone. However, according to exam instructions, you will need an EXTERNAL webcam.)

The time distribution of the final exam is also inhuman. In total, there are 8 questions. They split the exam into FOUR parts with 2 questions each. For each part, we are given ONLY 20 minutes to answer. Such arrangement would make student more panic if they, unfortunately, got disconnected in any parts, as this takes time to re-connect. Some may think this applies to all online exams, but in this case, the penalty of re-connecting is more costly as the answering time is already short.
(For me, I got disconnected on part 4. Luckily I managed to think of and open a Wi-Fi hotspot to finish the exam. But in the end, I left one question almost blank because of this.)

If you do follow the exam rules legitimately, this means that you have only 20 minutes to answer the question by writing down all the steps clearly, while you have to write down your information on EACH PAGE (Considering that you submit your work on Canvas, this is actually useless. But these are real exam rules: They need you to do that but you can only bring in BLANK papers, even though they do not check the papers in the end).
After that, we have only around 6 minutes to scan and upload our answers, and 2 minutes toilet break and prepare for the next part (This is extremely harsh to students who take the exam in some UG hall like hall 6, such that the toilet has a distance between rooms).
Maybe they think this helps to prevent cheaters but ironically this doesn’t help at all (Since they don’t open the mic and check monitors). This exam is definitely intense. I think it would be less harsh if they split it into fewer parts so we have more answering time for each question on average.

To sum up the arrangement of the final exam, it is basically making exam that COULD be easier into potential nightmare fuel by shortening time to answer and upload, while banning any assistance (Even though this happens to all math courses), wasting our time by writing unnecessary information and forcing us to use extra devices. This arrangement, I think, brings inconvenience to many students.


Although such arrangements would be less likely to happen again since HKUST is switching back to F2F in the next semester, I think these arrangements proved why you should avoid this professor AT ALL COSTS if you want more manageable exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Original grading scheme:
Assignments: 10%
Midterm: 30%
Final: 60%

Right after midterm (Please see teaching for more details):
Assignments: 10%
Final: 90%

The night after midterm, the grading scheme remains the same as before midterm.

The next day of midterm:
Assignments: 30%
Final: 70%

You may find 90% final is ridiculous. But it's ok because Professor Qian said It is NORMAL in UST.

If you really don't want to face such a ridiculous grading scheme, I suggest you take it in the fall semester instead (Likely to be taught by Dr. Ho). As I read from others' review, Prof. Qian allows students to not attend midterm and "all in" final, while unable to make sure that the difficulty of the assessments are fair enough to let students taking two different paths (30% midterm + 60% final, or 90% final) get a fair grade (This was done for at least two semesters taught by him). What makes this matter worse is that he doesn’t take the maximum score of these two pathways.

It is horrible that Prof. Qian over-relying on curving to try to make the grade balanced while making the exams long with tight time. Curving seems to make the grade curve more flexible in case most students cannot finish all questions in time, but this simply brings frustration and defeat.
Also, since he allowed students to skip midterm and “all-in” final in the past, curving becomes more unreliable as students were split into two groups with disproportionate efforts paid.

Imagine you have tried hard in midterm and got like 80 to 90, but it ended up cancelled. You headed on and still gave your best shot on the Final but end up getting 60. Is this fair to you? Definitely not, since you could have got at least a sub-grade higher if midterm is not completely cancelled, right?

My score is as follows:
Homework: 100% (You can repeatedly attempt and get 100%)
Final: 83/100 (Mean for L2: 62)
Final grade: A (88.1%)

In fact, my grade actually took the benefit from the new grading scheme, but I’m sorry that I still have to point out how ridiculous this sudden change of grading scheme is. Not to mention that the midterm is held at around week 11, near the end of the semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
For assignments, it is basically easy to handle. All 12 WeBWorK homework was opened at the beginning of the semester. So the students with solid calculus background may complete the first few early as a head start to minimize the worry later in the semester.

For the midterm, it is a WeBWorK-based midterm. This means you do it like how you do the homework. It consists of 28 questions modified from the homework. Even though we have calculators and formula sheets, however, we have to finish them in 1 hour, making the time is very tight to finish (And Prof. Qian did not expect us to finish it). Even though you may have spent days and days to clear the concept, did past papers and Classviva exercises, reviewed the WeBWorK questions, but sorry, technical problems, your efforts and time are in vain!

The final exam is a written exam. There are 8 long questions, but we are only given on average 10 minutes to finish one question (The arrangement on other items is also frustrating, see teaching section for more). Because of this, in order to get high marks, you have to train yourself to catch up with the pace, i.e. finish a question and list out all its steps within 10 minutes.
Despite such a harsh arrangement, I personally think the overall execution of this exam is at least better than the midterm.

According to one of my friend who studied in the 20-21 fall semester (Taught by Dr. Ho), I would expect the pace of this course would be rather relaxing, but my expectation simply broke apart after the cancellation of the midterm. Having a written exam is fine for me, but the pace of the exam is simply too tense.

It is sacrilege for a highly educated professor to say such words that contempt the efforts of students. Before this incident, I, as a student, trusted the teaching system works on HKUST, but now I will surely doubt that is the professor's decision absolute and if it is normal to "all in final" in UST? There is no way that student to yell out their voice. It is unacceptable that a professor said such irresponsible words. It is the responsibility of the professor to check whether the platform is suitable to have the exam.

Students who timed out from webwork also have their responsibility (I am not blaming the victim but just want to say) because their didn't constantly refresh their webwork page. It is not the first day that we use webwork, we all should know that webwork got a damn afk system that will log u out once u afk for 30 mins. reviews.author: 準雷
reviews.title: 一個設計得好好 真正適合engineer讀既MATH course
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Three Dimensional space, Vectors in the plane, Vectors in three dimensions, Dot products
Week 2: More examples on vectors and dot products, Cross products, Lines and planes in 3 space
Week 3: More examples on lines and planes, cylinders and quadric surfaces, Calculus I of vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Calculus II of vector-valued functions, Length of curves
Week 4: More examples on vector functions, functions of several variables, level curves, limits and continuity of functions of several variables
Week 5: Conversion between cylindrical, rectangular and spherical coordinate systems, partial derivatives, Chain rules
Week 6: Gradient vectors, Tangent planes
-----------------------Quiz-----------------------------
Week 7: Tangent planes on the aspect of approximation, Extreme values, More examples on gradient vectors
Week 8: Double integration on rectangular regions, double integration on general regions, polar coordinate system
Week 9: Double integrals in polar coordinate, surface area, triple integrals in rectangular coordinate system
Week 10: Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system, line integrals, vector fields and line integrals in vector fields
Week 11: Flux of a vector field, path independence, potential functions and conservative vector fields and Green’s theorem in the plane
Week 12: Surface integrals, flux of a vector field across a surface
Week 13: Divergence theorem and Stoke’s theorem
(Stoke’s theorem is excluded from Final Exam due to insufficient teaching time)
--------------Final Exam (cumulative)----------------

reviews.author: just_a_student
reviews.title: Worst Course I have ever taken
reviews.comment_content: To be perfectly honest the contents of the course itself its quite good, it's an introduction to doing calculus in a 3d space and dealing with multi-variable functions. However, with bad course construction, grading, and shit arrangement overall. What should have been an integral course in your engineering degree, became a full-on burden. In the end, courses like this make me wonder why I pay 70 000 HKD to attend this uni, I should have been paid to have to deal with this shit show of a course
reviews.comment_teaching:
Absolutely the worst, my assigned professor was not really a professor but a visiting post-doctoral fellow, who by no means was up to the task to teach this course. Not because he did not understand the material, but because he was just bad a teaching in general. The only saving grace for me is that the TA Tommy was really good and he provides good tutorials.

Teaching assignments like this makes me question what is the department thinking. Why would you hand the assignment to teach an integral math course for engineers to understand and fully comprehend to such a an incompetent teacher. Do they want us to fail?

Extra note the final exam hall was open late by 20 minutes, and I kid u not, the professor was screaming to hurry it up when the gates open glancing over the fact that it was their own fault to begin with.
reviews.comment_grading:
I haven't gotten my grade, but the Math department thought it was good idea to go with this grading schme
30% HW
70% Final Exam

that's it, it might look good cause it's less work, but that only applies if you understand the course. Considering this is a pretty challenging course that introduces many new concepts and elementary concepts that can be built upon, the fact that it had only a final made it very hard to gauge your actual understanding of the course and you can just easily feel left behind.

reviews.author: Anonymous1234
reviews.comment_content:
The content is pretty straight forward.
It covers the basics of multivariable calculus and if you are familiar with calculus and its concepts, this course is really not that hard.

The professor develops on the basic knowledge of calculus you previous had and just introduces second or third or more variables in to the equation.
reviews.comment_teaching: My professor was very well-prepared for his lectures and was not hesitant to answer any questions. Although it seems he is reading off the notes, he does introduce important details that are not in the notes from time to time so I highly recommend you participating the lectures. If you only look at the class notes (which is very helpful on its own) you may be unprepared for the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair but harsh.

It could be due to the online method of examination and assessments, but from what i can speculate, one question worth of points in the final exam is a letter grade.

I got over 75% and got an A.

If you do all your homework (which has near infinite attempts) and video presentation you get an easy 25% of your grade.

The midterm-quiz is 15%. Its important, but if you screw it up don't panic, just prepare well for the final exam.

The final is everything. Its 60% of your grade. Do it well. For anyone taking this course for 2021 spring... well,, good luck. One question is your letter grade so I hope you can perform your best.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is quite manageable as long as you spend one or two hours for assessment per week and another hour or two for revision. Guess you cant really have overwhelming workload for an introductory mathematics course.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: A superb multi-variable calculus course for engineers and DON'T GIVE UP U CAN GET A+
reviews.comment_content:
MATH 2011 is an easier version of its sibling course, MATH 2023.

This course targets at students from engineering school and has more emphasis on the applications of multi-variable calculus in engineering topics. The content covered will be useful for further studies in fluid mechanics, electronics etc.

Topics included:
1. Vectors, dot product, cross product and its applications
2. Lines, Planes and vector applications (** find shortest distance)
3. Cylinders and Surfaces
4. Vector-valued functions (limit, derivatives, integrals, tangent line, arc length and re-parametrizaton, sketching)

5. Function of two variables, domains, range, level curve, continuity, limit (use two path test to proof non-existence of limit)
6. Coordinate systems conversion
7. Partial Differentiation, chain rule (draw dependence chart), implicit differentiation
8. Gradient vectors, directional derivatives and its applications (normal line, tangent plane, equation of tangent line etc)
9. Linear approxiamtion
____________________________________

10. Extreme value and its applications

11. Double integration under general, rectangular region (Fubini's Theorem)
12. Double integration under polar coordinate system
13. Surface Area and its aoplications
14. Triple Integrals under rectangular and cylindrical coordinate system

15. Line Integrals under vector field (find work done/fluid flow)
16. Vector fields
17. Conservative vector field (find potential function, Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals, Path independence)
18. Divergence and Curl
19. Green's Theorem
20. Surface Area and Surface Integrals
21. Flux and Divergence Theorem

(Stoke's Theorem is omitted this semester)
reviews.comment_teaching:
I have no doubt to say that HHM saves my life and brings me back to heaven this semester since I didn't perform well in Year 1 Math courses.
He really devotes a lot in teaching and cares about the delivery of content. See below.

1. Lecture Notes
Printed colorful lecture notes are distributed in every lecture. The notes included most of the key concepts with detailed explanation, proofs and graphics. Dr Ho would explain the concepts in detail with his amazing great handwriting and sketching, as well as in-class demonstrations using different tools to help visualize the effects of concepts. Not only concepts would be delivered, he also spends time on computing significant examples, explaining in a way that you should have no problem to understand well. The content are well delivered and organized in general. I never find his lecture boring since he is really serious in teaching and the logic is easy to follow since he acts like a robot with his distinctive tone.

Some examples of Dr. Ho lecture presentation
Things to do: When we compute .....
Is that true for ....? Please raise up your hand? one, two, three... thank you! thank you! The answer is NONE OF THEM!
Draw smiling faces :) :) :)  then he smiles with his creepy face :)
please fasten your seatbelt
This is the first, second, third reminder ...... (He is an email sadist)

2. Additional Examples on Canvas
Dr. Ho won't cover the additional examples in class but I still recommend you to print them out and understand the materials. These help you to get a concrete and integrated understanding between topics.


Tutorials:
My tutor is Tommy Cheng. Although he speaks Konglish and broken English really well, he is able to demonstrate extra examples which are not covered in lectures. His tutorials are basically using the notes prepared by Einstein and the whole tutorial is simply examples drilling.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two types of grading are provided this semester.

Scheme I: 10% WebWork, 30% Midterm, 60% Final
Scheme II: 10% WebWork, 90% Final

Webwork *6
Midterm 15-MCQs with 90 mins
Final (changed to Canvas online exam due to nCOV-19 and social movement)
12-MCQs 1hr

It turns out that most students didn't perform well in Midterm due to its difficulty in asking integrated concepts and applications. However, the final exam is much easier than expected and the time provided is quite sufficient. I wonder why there are still a lot of students work poorly and the mean is that low.

Statistics:
Webwork Full Mark
Midterm 36/45 --> 80/100 (Mean: 24/45, S.D 10.6, >1.13 SD)
Final 44/48 --> 92/100 (Mean 28/48, S.D 10.2)
Overall grading follow Scheme II
Total Score: 92.5%
Grade: A+
(WTF I can't imagine I've two 2000-level math courses with A+, I completely screwed up for 1000-level Math courses)

HHM hurray! He is no longer killer Ming :) Don't give up btw:)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite high if you really want to receive good grade in this course. But I would say the workload is manageable if you really do a lot of hard-work working on exercises and concepts clarifications.

The WebWork are generally shit, you can just finish all the required work and simply omit it during revision.

My way of revising the course:
1. Read and understand the lecture notes with examples, concepts and proofs. Review the additional notes posted on Canvas.
2. Work on most tutorial exercises and textbook exercises as supplement (Textbook: Calculus Early Transcedental)
3. Find extra examples and application problems onliine since Dr. Ho didn't cover all the tricky parts and techniques. Personally suggest watching Youtube videos provided by Prof. Leonard, this is my major source for understanding the advanced examples and computational tricks in deep.

reviews.author: FrostyP4nc4kes
reviews.title: Watch professor leonards videos! (Link is in teaching section of this review)
reviews.comment_content:
Overall the content is interesting, and easier than Math1014.

The most annoying part is memorising all the formulas like
arclength, unit tangent, unit normal, curvature >_>. the list kinda just goes on.

if you can do derivatives, you can do partial derivatives. you legit just treat all but one of the variables like it is a constant, and then you take the derivative.

double integration is more of a nuisance. If you know how to do the set-up, you can do anything the teacher throws at you. please get comfortable with polar regions because they are a life saver. You don't have to worry about spherical coordinates in this course.

triple integration is just double integration except its annoying as frick. if you ever want to change the order of integration(which in double integration, you have to draw the 2d region), ur gonna have to draw out a nice 3d surface, or a ton of 2d regions and use ur brain and figure out what to do from there. you better pray you don't have to do triple integral bound changes on the exam :) ALSO, there is a way to avoid trig sub that isn't taught in class. Its called the jacobian, please for the love of God learn jacobian substitution on your own.

Vector fields: we basically skipped everything useful this semester >_< we can do line integrals over vector fields and conservative vector fields. But we never learnt green's, stoke's or divergence theorem, which are really important for engineering courses.


looking back, i regret not doing 2023. If you want a complete package of multivariable calc, do math2023.
reviews.comment_teaching:
LOL I skipped 90% of lectures, and watched a few lecture replays and looked at lecture notes(which are actually very good tbh). From the videos i did watch, prof Qian was a good teacher, but he just doesn't cover everything in depth enoughj. Also, he doesn't give you enough practice and examples to make you feel comfortable with the subject, which is fair given we only have 80-minute classes.

I actually just watched all the relevant videos from this dude called professor Leonard. If you want an A, watch this mans videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tGVnBAHLApA&list=PLDesaqWTN6ESk16YRmzuJ8f6-rnuy0Ry7&index=3&ab_channel=ProfessorLeonard

Seriously this man is maths jesus, he will save your soul from the pain of getting an F in this class :)
reviews.comment_grading:
Prof Qian took all the feedback from last year's students, who complained about having a 70% final with 30% webwork, and threw it in to a bin, and set the bin on fire. Cuz this sem was 75% final, 25% webwork. Very nice.

This combined with the online exam format which is hella stressful, made the exam season very funn't.

I recommend following up with the graders when you feel like they have marked you unfairly.

IF YOUR ANSWER IS NOT THE SAME AS THE KEY, THEY MIGHT UNDERLINE SOMETHING RANDOM AND MARK YOU OFF!!!(not just in this class but also in elec2420 this happened to me >:( )

SOME GRADERS LIKE TO TAKE OFF WAY MORE MARKS THAN NECESSARY. I flipped bounds on 1 integral, made a small algebraic mistake, and got 2 out of 13 for that question. (sadly the grade was already set before I could argue my case ;-; so please make sure you argue with the graders as soon as possible if you feel like you deserve more points)
While initially, graders will be very strict, they are actually very nice and will be ok with giving you a few points back :)

In the end:
webwork: 93.34%
Exam: 81% mean: 52.73
Total: 84.09-> A

Putting other reviews in the picture, if you want an A, it looks like you need 25-30% score above mean to secure an A
reviews.comment_workload: very low, but very annoying. Webwork questions are so algebraically annoying i cant.

reviews.author: An225 Mriya
reviews.title: Auferstanden aus Ruinen
reviews.comment_content:
Course content includes:
*General introduction of 3D space
*Vectors and vector operation
*Lines and planes in 3D space
*Vector functions
*Multivariable functions
*Partial differentiation and its application, including:
**Maximum/minimum values of multivariable functions
**Gradient vectors
**Surface planes
*Partial integrals
*Double and triple integrals by various forms of Fubini's theorem
*Introduction to vector field
*Conservative vector fields and Green's Theorem

While mentioned in other previous reviews, the divergence theorem and Stoke’s theorem were not taught, though Professor Ho did encourage us to self-learn them if we want to have a more solid understanding on multivarible calculus.

Previous M2 experience may help with understanding vectors, but after the topic of 3D lines and planes, you can no longer rely on your previous knowledge. These knowledge will be useful when you learn further in your major (eg. MECH2210 for MECH/AE students).
reviews.comment_teaching:
In general, Professor Ho teaches in a slow, steady, yet easy-to-understand way. As a local professor, his accent is understandable, and he also maintain fairly vibrant interactions in lectures. While previously reported that the course's notes must be taken from his lectures, all lecture notes are available on Canvas this semester.

One of his specialty is using paper and coloured pens instead of using pre-made PowerPoint during teaching, which helps with understanding the 3D coordinate system and drawing. Examples discussed in lectures are also dissected in details and guided step-to-step, with more emphasis on application than proof, though you can listen to his explanation should you know learn deeper.

I'll consider him similar to Merkel: not exceptionally shiny or attractive in teaching, but with sufficient experience, he also teaches well.

Speaking of the TA, Ho Ming Leung is as unremarkable as other MATH TAs I've experienced before: Simply finding today tutorial's notes, and do questions in front of us, in which I mostly uses the time to do questions by myself. Another criticism is that he used unproportionate time to explain some easy contents, like the answer of one presentation question, while simply don't mention about other contents (like how to solve midterm questions) we'll concern more.

P.S. As mentioned by other students, Professor Ho is known for repeatedly sending email notifications to us (probably on average, 5-6 emails per notification). While regular cleanup can be a solution, your email system organizes forwarded/replied emails into a single one, so you may also opt to delete all notifications when he don't repeat them and you consider they're useless.
reviews.comment_grading:
6 assignments: 10% (All full marks)
2 presentations: 10% (All full marks)
Midterm: 30% (24/33) (Mean: 16.72/33, SD 6.29)
Final: 50% (21/45) (Mean: 24.16/45, SD 7.58)
Total: 65.15/100 (Mean: 60.99/100, SD 13.34)
*Both the midterm and final exams are in MC format, and both contains an impossible-to-fail question asking you about the colour of the question paper.

The assignments and presentations are easy, and midterm questions are also generally easy as well: only part of the questions are more troublesome.

The final is another story though: they're simply not on the level as questions in textbooks and assignments. While they're not particularly tricky and I can figure out what they're testing on, they are extremely TEDIOUS. For example, a vector field given in one question can contain 5 terms with all elementary functions you can imagine.

Ultimately I think I resorted to wild guessing for half of the questions in the final, and ultimately get a B at the end. As a guy who get demoted to C-range in last MATH1014, I think recovery to B-range should be fine with me this time...
reviews.comment_workload:
There are in total 6 online assignments published on WebWork, in which they're similar to Classviva assignments in previous MATH1013 and 1014: you can (and are encouraged to, for your grade) spam correct answers with ease.

The presentation questions only contain 1 question per presentation, and are also easy (one question is mentioned on lectures to be similar to a lecture example). You should get full marks as long as you present a correct answer and speak satisfactorily.

As a result, most of the workload comes from preparing for the midterm and final exams.

reviews.author: 高海千歌
reviews.title: Good professor and teaching, but be aware of Mark Six MC exam
reviews.comment_content:
1 Three-Dimensional space (section 12.1), Vectors in the plane (section 12.2) , Vectors in three dimensions (section 12.2) ,Dot products (section 12.3)
2 More examples on vectors and dot products, Cross products (section 12.4), Lines and planes in 3-space (section 12.5)

3 More examples on lines and planes, cylinders and quadric surfaces (section 12.6), Calculus I of vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Calculus II of vector-valued functions, Length of curves (section 13.1, 13.2, 13.3)

4 More examples on vector functions, functions of several variables, level curves, ,limits and continuity of functions of several variables (section 14.1, 14.2)

5 Conversion between cylindrical, rectangular and spherical coordinate systems, partial derivatives, Chain rules (section 14.3, 14.4, 14.5)

6 Gradient vectors, Tangent planes (section 14.6)

7 Tangent planes on the aspect of approximation, Extreme values, More examples on gradient vectors (section 14.7)

8 Double integration on rectangular regions, double integration on general regions, polar coordinate system (section 15.1, 15.2, 15.3)

9 Double integrals in polar coordinate, surface area, triple integrals in rectangular coordinate system (section 15.4, 15.6, 15.7)

10 Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system (section 15.8), line integrals, vector fields and line integrals in vector fields (section 16.1, 16.2)

11 Flux  of  a  vector  field,  path  independence,  potential  functions  and  conservative  vector fields and Green’s theorem in the plane (section 16.3, 16.4, 16.5, 16.6)

12 Surface integrals, flux of a vector field across a surface (section 16.7)

I think these concepts are useful in engineering so try to learn better.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Just like other comments suggest, Dr. Ho teaches very well. I highly appreciate it.

Light accent. The pace is very easy to catch up. His step-by-step explanation on example question is very clear and easy to follow as well. The logic flow of concepts or question in lecture notes are well explained.

Moreover, he knows this course is more emphasizing on application rather than proof (those should belongs to MATH2023). Therefore, he usually uses time on explaining concepts or demonstrating example questions, rather than making excess proofing

Therefore, Dr.Ho is a really good professor for people who does not have strong math background like me. If you follow his progress in class well, you are able to grasp a solid foundation and get good result.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good, at least comparing with my other MATH course (1013 1014 2111)

Grading Scheme:
1. Webwork 10%
2. Presentation 10%
3. Midterm 30%
4. Final 50%

Result:
Webwork : 100% (Mean : 94.503%)
Presentation 1 : 5/5 (Mean : 4.53/5)
Presentation 2 : 5/5 (Mean : 4.74/5)
Midterm : 24/33 = 72.73%
(Mean : 17.14/33  SD : 6.29)
Final : 30/45 = 66.67%
(Mean : 24.08/45  SD : 7.58)

Overall : 75.15%  Grade : A-

I am very touching that I can get an A range in MATH course as I am a math idiot...Also I am quite surprised that you can get A range with less than 80% (It looks like 70% or above already have a chance). This course actually has a quite high cost-effectiveness. Therefore, try to put more effort in it.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not that much. At least compared with my another compulsory MATH2111, the workload here is somewhat friendly.

1. Webwork
For this semester, only 6 Webwork homework, which is less than my expectation (For my MATH2111 there are like 11-12 homework in one semester...)

2. Presentation
The presentation is a little bit troublesome. You are given a question and you need to solve it and make a recording, explaining the steps. Nevertheless, the question itself is not that complicated. Moreover, there are only ONE question only. Solving it is not a big deal. If you don't get stuck for too long, the time of solving+recording may even less than one webwork, which is actually quite friendly indeed.

However, find a way to check answer (google, wolframalpha, your friends, etc.) because if your answer is wrong, you will be in big trouble.

3. Mid-term & Final exam
I don't know whether Dr.Ho is lazy and just want to scan the MC answer sheet by machine, or he wants us to experience what Mark Six is or whatever, even though it comes back to physical exam, the format is still ALL MC. Therefore, be very careful as one question may cost you one subgrade. In contrast, sometimes if you get stuck, guessing may bring you unexpectedly good result (If this happens, you should go and buy Mark Six)

For preparing exams, there are no other way -- just do exercises (Of course you need to make sure you have clear concepts beforehand). Dr.Ho will provide a set of revision exercises. You can also do tutorial exercise or even re-do the example question in lecture notes as the exam will just ask some similar things. Nothing tricky at all.

Don't think the exam is very easy though. Make sure you can compute things quickly and accurately. Even though the example question and exam asks the same thing, the given expression may become very horrible in exam.

For example, a given vector field in lecture notes may be just <x, x+y>. But in my final exam, it becomes an expression with four to five terms, with product, quotient or even square roots inside, which make the computation become extremely tedious = =

reviews.author: ptrknow
reviews.comment_content:
You can say there are a lot of new concepts in this course:
- Equations of lines and planes in space
- Space curves
- Differential Calculus of Multivariable Functions (Limit, continuity, partial derivatives, chain rule, tangent plane, max and min)
- Multiple Integrals (Double and Triple Integrals)
- Vector Calculus (Line integral, surface integral, flux, divergence, potential, and the three fundamental theorems that link between concepts of multiple integrals and vector calculus)
(Note: Stokes' Theorem was not tested)

It is like cramming the whole 1013 and 1014 into one course, and adding more new things at the same time.

However, you can also say many of them are old things that are just some extended versions to 2D plane or 3D space of the things that are already taught in 1013 and 1014.

So, if you have to take this course, you are encouraged to do better in 1013 and 1014, which helps you get a better picture between the many different concepts introduced here. This possibly makes the course significantly easier.

Or else, you may well need to re-visit the concepts in 1013 and 1014 frequently, and simultaneously learning many "new" things. That would be no good, right?
reviews.comment_teaching:
+ 5 well-written notes. Precise and concise, but not lacking in details. Many diagrams are provided (can be enlarged though).
+ Compared to HHM's notes, Henry's notes contain more examples with higher difficulty
+ 7 problem sets. Quite a number of questions can be difficult. Very helpful for preparation of exams
+ Good command of English. Clear delivery of materials.
+ Comprehensive (In fact, he was the only instructor who was able to finish all the things this semester, i.e. triple integrals in spherical coordinates and Stokes' Theorem are also taught. Of course, Lagrange's Multiplier and Jacobian will not be included)
+ Lecture videos are provided

- Boring?? Maybe a little bit. But he taught well, and this is good enough.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm
15 MCs in 75 min. Mean should be around 9-10 MC.

Final
13 MCs + 4 Long questions. Total 90 marks.
Mean: 46.15/90
SD: 17.8

Although the mean is not high, but to be honest, the exam questions are just textbook-level problems. In other words, whether or not you are familiar with the method of dealing with the typical problems is decisive to your grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
The official workload is really light. Just 6 webworks. Lectures and tutorials are not taking attendance (plus the lectures will provide videos).

Still, doing more exercises is necessary, if you want to score well.

Typical MATH grading. Quite bad as missing 1-2 questions equal 1 subgrade. Mean about C+.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: COULD've been fun.
reviews.comment_content:
Multivariable Calculus:
Coordinate systems
Plane and line equations
Parametric equations
Vectors, dot and cross product

Multivariable Limits
Partial Differentiation
Gradient vector
Extreme values
Iterated (double/triple) integral

Pretty important stuff, and much easier to understand compared to the mess that is MATH1014, the contents are not bad and actually quite fun!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Qian is quite good at teaching, he has a slight accent but the course material is explained very clearly through the lectures and his handwritten notes. The notes are well-made too with examples and graphs to show what you are really doing, I wished there was video visualizations to explain the examples even more clearly but overall the lectures were good.

However due to his failure in handling the midterm, I put the teaching at a D, details explained in the grading section.

Tutorial attendance is not necessary, therefore I attended none of them.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Homework
70% Final

Originally there was a midterm, conducted on WebWork, however during the midterm, when students submitted their answers, the answers were wiped and students could not submit their answers. Turns out that the system requires students to preview their answers before submitting them (something that was never required when students used WebWork to do their homework).

Despite this, a LARGE MAJORITY (80%+) of students were able to submit their answers through various methods (answers saved in browser cache, screenshotting the page, etc), originally a makeup midterm was held for the affected students, but since a vocal minority complained (they even begged to the entire course on email, somehow unable to deselect "reply to all"), the midterm was cancelled for everyone, good effort on their part, but unfortunate for the others.

To add to this, the midterm was also really dumb, you had to do almost 30 questions, which is basically impossible and the professor even said you AREN'T expected to finish all of them, all the questions were very basic calculations, and did not require more than memorization, so I am not too upset that it was cancelled.

The final was much more normal, 8 questions in 80 minutes, answers written on paper and scanned to submit, much better than the midterm, questions were not TOO difficult. Mean: 62/100

I got full marks on homework, mean on exam. Overall I was about 2% higher than mean, and got a B, decent grading but again the assessment methods in this course are quite bad.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is light, just do the WebWork every week, which only has 7 questions, you can also just google the questions if you get unfortunately stuck, answers and steps could be found online, no Chegg required.

Spent a few days studying for the midterm, wasted effort however since the midterm was cancelled and we were told to treat this midterm as "an exercise". As for the final, I spent quite a lot of time really trying to understand the details and concepts (particularly chapter 15!), and doing the past papers.

Sometimes students of other instructors will come to Dr Ho class. Attendance may be taken to ensure those enrolled have a seat.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Ho is great at teaching this course and goes from easy concepts to challenging ones gradually and he's really good at explaining each theorem very thoroughly with examples, step-by-step. Def recommend him. I go to his class every time.

Not good at math but got an A

6 online webwork homework which is not heavy workload in my opinion
The individual presentation questions are not difficult at all and you can always ask your classmates for the solution
the quiz and exam is not very difficult if you study hard and review the tutorial notes of your TA and do the exercises prepared for you
The material is not easy as you learn the last half of the content so you need extra effort and a stronger foundation of math to ace in the final though because only 16 out of 6XX people got full marks for it

reviews.author: Brace
reviews.comment_content: 細節我唔講啦，主要係 3d graph, vector, integration, 多重integration （最多三重）, vector field, 同埋 vector 應用於 integration。
reviews.comment_teaching:
首先英文清晰並流暢。
其次prof講嘢有耐心，寫字都十分標誌，會感受到佢真係明白啲concept並想教畀我哋。不過太有耐心，好少見佢跳步，就算呢一步用嘅concept學過都一一解釋，老實講仲不如花多啲時間喺解釋新嘢上面。而且有時會用好多句子重複同一個意思。
不過最重要嘅係聽得明佢講咩。

15% online HW

其實 quiz、final 比 HW、presentation 唔係難太多，明concept嘅話一半分係易攞嘅。根據prof，course 裡面所有同學嘅 final 表現 normally distributed，600個人有十幾個滿分。

Very clear explanation. HO prepared his lecture notes and talked about the concepts. Moreover, the lecture recordings are uploaded in canvas very quickly, which is good for us to have some reviews.

The TA, KONG, is also good. He has his own website from which we can download the materials. The notes are well-organised and there are many exercises.

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: Good course with low workload.
reviews.comment_content: Basic multivariable Calculus stuff. Tips for preparing for the midterm and final: please focus more on calculating the distance in midterm, and please focus more on calculating the line integrals and flux after midterm. The whole course is mainly about differentiation and integration and the rest is not emphasized.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is really very good. Please please Pleeeease value this professor because it is really hard to meet another professor who is as good as him in teaching engineering maths course in the maths department of ust. His lecture notes are also amazing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 15%
Webwork 15%
Presentation 2*5%
Final 40%
The only bad part of this course is that many useless, stupid, sick fuckwads would cheat in BOTH MIDTERM and FINAL. But it would be fine as long as you study hard because it is easy to get full marks. (Some of the people who cheated even score lower than me, how RIDICULOUS. Honestly, if a person needs to cheat in THIS course in order to do well, the latter engineering courses and maths courses would SURELY be a disaster for them LOL. Because this course is fundamental AND important. You would use it all the time in ELEC, MECH, CENG, CIVL, MATH and some of the COMP courses. )

But you can always refer to his lecture recordings to find out the clearest way to explain them. Never attended tutorials but it is not that much of a problem because the midterm and final are not hard as long as you attend all the lectures and review his lecture notes before exams.

reviews.author: Jayce
reviews.comment_content: You can all find it easily as it is a required subject for engineers. There are no midterms and I don't quite remember the weighting of hw and final but its around 15% hw and 85% final. I got 100% at the end
reviews.comment_teaching: I did not attend a lot of lessons. I just revised the notes on myself. Don't be like me and attend lessons and tutorials. The professor is good, but I can also quite understand on my own.
reviews.comment_grading: There are no midterms this semester, only the final. So the grading is largely based on your completion on homework and undoubtedly the final. I scored a full mark on finals, and it is really easy as the questions are exactly the same in homework (well the numbers aren't the same obviously). There is even 5 submission chances so you most definitely can score a full mark. When the grade is released, there was heated debate on the grading because everyone was scoring a full mark, the school cannot give so many As to student. As a result, the mark was based on the submission attempts which is quite unfair 'cause it wasn't mentioned before. At the end (I don't know how they calculated my marks 'cause I submitted 4 times I guess) I got an A+, this was the first A range I've ever gotten.
reviews.comment_workload: In this semester there are only weakly homework and have a rather sufficient time (i.e. 2 weeks) to complete all of it. There are unlimited tries on each problem so you don't have to worry that you get the answer wrongly.

reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching pace is appropriate or maybe a bit slow and boring for some people who have learned some of the topics already. All files given in this semester are a scan version of his hand-written notes in B&W (so u can't search any keywords when revising and u may better print them out) , and u may sometimes need to refer to the coloured graph in another file folder. For tutorials, the TA is quite willing to help u out with ur own questions after class. Though, both lectures and tutorials suffer from broken internet from time to time, draging the class quite a bit.
reviews.comment_grading:
WebWork 25%
Final 75%
No midterm this sememter

My score:
HW 24.77/25 (99.08%)
Final 75/75

WebWork has about 12 sets, each having about 5-8 questions. There are no deduction of multiple trials, i.e. you can try till you get the correct ans and get full 25% easily (I just simply forgot to submit one of them)

Final is almost the same as those questions in WebWork, and you are given 5 submissions in total for the 20 questions. If you go over the HW once before the final, you can surely get 100% (which I believe more than half students did it). He tried to count the wrong attempts in the final because of this, but at last he sticked to the orginal marking scheme for not counting them, and I got A in this semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
Just WebWork
Won't take u much time to do one set each week
Or u may still choose to be a deadline fighter lol

reviews.author: anonymity
reviews.title: Good course, good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Parametric and polar curve, vectors and vector-valued function, functions of several variables, multiple integration, vector calculus.
For me, most of the content are easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good teaching.Although this is an online course, professor tries to make the concept very clear using diagram stuff. He also shows every step of derivation for new concepts.
Professor is willing to answer questions.
reviews.comment_grading: 25% for hw and 75% for final. All done in webwork system. The final was easy, questions were very similar to hw. Almost half of the students got full marks within 5 submissions, professor decided to take incorrect submissions into account. However professor did not mention beforehand and the system also recorded blank answers, which was very unfair. Overall, the exam was easy, but the grading system was somehow unsatisfying.
reviews.comment_workload: 12 hw in total, each consisting of  6-7 problems. The problems in hw are useful.Maybe you should finish one piece every week.

reviews.author: Junny Liu
reviews.title: The class with the highest return
reviews.comment_content:
Differentiation in several variables, with applications in approximation, maximum and minimum and geometry. Integration in several variables, vector analysis.
The course covers 24 chapters. I think it’s appropriate.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would say he’s somewhat boring in teaching but he actually explains everything clearly. If you have patience, I believe you’ll understand everything if you attend classes. However, you can also self-learn like me.
But do remember he only gives out paper notes during classes. No online version nor make-up notes. So do remember to pick it up.
He writes very good notes, that I’ll give credit.
reviews.comment_grading:
10%assignment+30%midterm+60%final
Or 10%assignment + 90%final
The grade took me by surprise. It was way better than I expected.
Since the midterm and final were only 10+ multiple questions, I thought I’ll be screwed if I missed any questions at all. But it turned out     13/15 in midterm and 9/12 in final got me an A, so I think it’s probably the class with the highest return rate that I’ve ever taken.
reviews.comment_workload:
You don’t need to learn the course everyday even if you don’t go to class. Just spend some time before each assignment. And then you’ll just need a efficient weekend to prepare  for midterm, and may be a week before final.
Overall, the workload is quite small compared to other math courses.

reviews.author: Anisha
reviews.title: much much better than MATH1014!
reviews.comment_content:
Till midterms, its all easy vector stuff that we need as tools to solve actual multivariable calculus problems. Most of it is covered in high school and there is only some new concepts and formulae. The real calculus part comes after midterms which is not too difficult if you are good in single variable calculus and imagining stuff in 3D. But line integrals and vector fields might be a bit challenging later.

Midterm exam is a piece of cake so mean is high but finals was a bit more challenging.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Qian is very enthusiastic about teaching and explains everything in detailed manner. Even though, he does only 1 problem per section in class, its pretty easy to understand. But you need to practice plenty on your own to do well. He also makes jokes but is very strict about using mobile phones in class.

Yi gave very good practice worksheets which if you could do on your own, would be enough to prepare for exams. However, his answer sheet is very basic and does not show how he went on with the problem, maybe only has the 1st and last step and no explanation in between. He also speeded through every tutorial which was a nightmare for us. So I suggest asking him in email or after class about the problems.

reviews.comment_content:
it's essential for any engineering discipline.

For civil engineering, this course is very important for fluid mechanics, and therefore hydrosystems engineering. Fluid is a painful course, but having a good grasp of multivariable will definitely help a lot.

For computer science, it's not a required course but it's strongly recommended to take this one or Math2023, since multivariable is really fundamental for machine learning/vision graphics/etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: I really like Prof Leung's teaching. It's sad that I couldn't get a chance to take his class again in math3312.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good. Note that if you are an engineering student and you go to math 2023. the grade will likely be lower than you will get in this course, that's just because your opponents in 2011 are engineers while those in 2023 are math&phys majors plus ECOF majors.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. In fact even lighter than math2111.

reviews.author: You-Know-Who
reviews.title: Very impressive!
reviews.comment_content:
This is a course in multi variable calculus. Topics include vectors and geometry of lines and surfaces, partial differentiation of functions of several variables and its applications in linear approximation, maximum and minimum, multiple integrals, line and surface integrals, and vector analysis.
The material after midterm is more difficult, especially those line and surface integrals so practice more on these topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr Ho is very careful in his teaching. He always teaches us step by step and tries to provide the most professional and precise explanation . Although I was very sleepy during the morning lecture and learnt very roughly in the class, it was still not that hard to follow his pace.
reviews.comment_grading:
Similar to other math courses:
midterm (30%)
final(60%)
webwork(10%) Six sets of webwork in total, 8 to 10 question per set.

I  got 1.3 SD higher than mean in the midterm and 1 SD higher than mean in the final and finally got A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Since I was always very sleepy in the class, I could not fully focus so I usually review it right after the class to refresh my memory and learn the whole lecture notes again by myself. Usually it took me about 1 hour.
Before you take the midterm and final, you had better do all the exercises not only from the lecture notes, but the additional exercises in Canvas, provided by Dr Ho, simply because if you do so and get familiar with all the exercises, the midterm and final will not be a hard time. You can even see the same questions in midterm and final. I skipped most tutorial class and  I didn't even spend a lot of time reviewing the tutorial notes. Perhaps if you listen carefully and do more tutorial exercises, you can get A+.
The key suggestion is that always remember to do all the exercises in lecture notes and Canvas !

reviews.author: Heinrich
reviews.title: Luckily it is over
reviews.comment_content: The content is too much. There are far more content than an average student can handle. You are not only required to understand the content, but also to work out the mathematical problem savvily within merely one semester. That is a little bit too harsh.
reviews.comment_teaching: I would say, everything is too quick. Given that the content is already huge, he did not spend much time on details. Once you don't understand some content in the lectures, you are never going to understand the theorems derived from that particular topic and you will be lagged behind severely.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is not very good. I witness many of my friend failing the course. The second time they take it they just got a barely satisfactory grade, provided that they have already given one more semester-worth of effort. I personally feel fortunate not to have failed.
reviews.comment_workload: As I have said above, learning those contents is quite a tough work. Luckily the Webwork tasks somehow guide us to do revision. Still, the frequency of assignments was higher than my speed of understanding. I made multiple trials to finish almost every quetion.

reviews.author: HelloDude
reviews.comment_content:
This course splits into two main topics: Vectors and Calculus.

For vectors, the course includes basic vectors calculation like addition, subtraction, dot product and cross product of vectors. It also teaches how to find planes and lines equations by vectors. And gradient vectors and directional derivatives is included too.

For calculus, partial derivatives, double and triple integrals, line integral, surface integrals, Green's Theorem and Divergence Theorem. Maybe includes Stroke's Theorem but the lecturer didn't have enough time to finish it so it didn't appear in final exam.

For me, the most difficult topics are using vectors to find distances between two lines/planes and surface integrals. But overall the calculus part is easier than the vector part.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Ho really teaches with the heart. He always give colour lecture notes with lots of pictures and examples for students and speaks clearly step by step. Because he won't use powerpoint but handwritting instead, you have to mark down many contents in your notes. And no lecture notes are uploaded online so you need to attend his class to get the notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
My midterm score was just at mean but the final exam score was 1.5 SD above the mean. Finally I got A.
Midterm: mean 35/60 sd 11
Final: mean 60/100 sd 22
reviews.comment_workload: The most workload comes from webwork and studying at home, easy peasy.

final (L1: mean:59.87 sd;26.88; L2: mean:51.09 sd:29.81)

The mid term and the final are very easy. You only simply need to remember some formulas and you can get full marks in the mid term.The time for mid term is 1 hour. I think the best student can finish it in 20 minutes.

The time for the final is 3 hours. I think most students can finish it in 1.5 hours. Nearly half of students left early in the exam. The final exam is straightforward. Just try not to make any mistakes. One little mistake will make you lose 4-5 marks.

Grading:
total marks:90% A
total marks:76% B+

reviews.comment_content:
Vectors; Partial Derivatives; Multiple Integration; Vector Calculus.
Not difficult but useful enough for engineering students.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching was really good and attractive. Though I only went to the lecture once, that might be the second best lecture I've ever had in UST (First belongs to Prof. Kursun). BTW, Prof. Qian doesn't like his students to use mobile phones in his classes, and I think his lecture would be more attractive than Clash of Royale. The lecture notes are all hand-written. Though can't use ctrl+F, it's still very useful and informative.
reviews.comment_grading:
10%HW+30%mid+60%final
Grading is appropriate, 96% is enough to get A+.
Doing well in final is a lot more important than doing well in midterm.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light as all assignments are released in the first week, thus unlike other math courses, it will be possible to finish a month's homework ahead of time. But if you want to get good grade, fully understand all parts and all examples in the notes is really important.

reviews.author: Richard L
reviews.comment_content: The content is relatively easy to grasp, and it progressively gets harder to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ho is a really good teacher, as he can help visualize concepts through his drawings and lecture notes, making the teaching really clear. It's recommended to come to lectures, as his explanations really aid the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair, as final grade consist of mid-term exam, final exam, and homework (10% for homework). A few questions from the exams are from selected questions from Prof. Ho, making it relatively harder to get good grade. I think no questions in the exams are out of scope, in terms of what have been taught in the lectures.
reviews.comment_workload: Appropriate workload for an introductory course. Homework come from WeBWorK, and there were only 10 of those; each very good practices for the concepts learned from lectures. Regarding optional works, there are tutorial questions and selected questions from Prof. Ho. Some questions from the tutorial exercises were sometimes out of scope of the lectures. But other than that tutorial questions are quite helpful to prepare for exams. There were also selected questions from Prof. Ho (posted in Canvas), which I find to be easier yet as helpful as the tutorial exercises. These questions usually come up in the mid-term and final exams, too.

reviews.author: GK
reviews.comment_content:
There are several topics covered, including vector, multi-variable calculus, field, flux etc. It seems quite useful in the future studies especially if you are in Physics, Maths or Mech major. Most of the content is similar to this page: http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/CalcIII/CalcIII.aspx
It is recommended to self-study this web since the lecture notes are too difficult to read.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ho Hon Ming is famous for his color notes which can only be obtained on lesson. He will do the examples of the lecture notes in the lectures. The steps in the lecture notes are full of words so if you like reading, it is good for you. However, I am not that kind of person.
reviews.comment_grading: Terrible paper makes the grading terrible. The exam paper are almost the same as the examples in the lecture notes. Not even the numbers are changed. As a result, plenty students get good score and most of the people are concentrated in 7X%. This makes the grading terrible. You might be getting a B because you are 1 mark higher than the other who get C+. Mean is around C+ I think? But that's why he is called killer Ming.
reviews.comment_workload: 6 webworks only, even lighter than the other math courses. But be notified that the deadline might be set weird like the 11:00 am rather than pm. This has faked so many people. If you are still being taught by him, you can attend the tutorial for just a brief understanding, grab his lecture notes without listening to him and recite all the examples in lecture notes before the exam. Don't care about tutorial notes, they will not be tested.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Qian was very good at teaching, you will never get bored in his class. Sometimes, he will ask some challenging math concepts in the class. But don’t worry, you can just treat these questions as fun questions. Qian was also passionate about answering students' questions after class. However, he is quite strict on class discipline. If you talk with others or use mobile phones in his class so significantly, he will stop you.

Tommy was not so good at teaching but it is very worthful to get his tutorial notes from his websites. The tutorial exercises are very adequate for you to kill the exam. You can find Tommy in math support centre.

Actually, I missed maybe 50% of Qian's class. I mainly study this course through Youtube. In youtube, you can find so many materials relevant to this course.

The final exam, it late for 20 minutes. Qian was pushy and rude to let students hurry up and sit for the exam. WTF? The math department was late to the exam, you made fault but you are pushy to let students hurry up? The organization of the exam was quite frustrating.
reviews.comment_grading:
25% HW(12)
75% final

All 12 HW is opened on Webwork since the end of the add-drop period. You can finish them anytime but there was a deadline for each HW, an averagely per 1-2 weeks. So you are recommended to finish 1 HW per 1 week.

HW: The hw work question is quite standard but a little questions can be challenging.
Exam: 10 LQ, No MC. The exam questions are also quite standard plus 1-2 weird questions. If you have done a lot of questions in Classviva and past papers uploaded by Qian, the exam is much easier for you.
The final exam mean was 48.13 and I got 72.
The overall mean was 59.06 and I got 79.
Finally, my grade is A-
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload is 12 hw. However, if you want to get a good grade, you have to finish the extra exercise in Classviva or the tutorial exercise given by Tommy Cheng. This would take you a lot of time.

reviews.title: Good Grade&Good Teaching&Horrible Arrangement
reviews.comment_content:
The same as what other posts said.
Green's Theory and Divergence are not covered due to the holidays in the semester.
The covered contents are pretty easy and straightforward,(compared to MATH2111?) you can understand what the new lecture is about even without attending the previous one.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Qian's lecture is great and all notes are hand-written. I did not attend the tutorial as the lecture was enough for those who paid attention.

Now comes to the horrible exam arrangement. For the details, please refer to the longest post. Within the whole disaster, Prof. Qian's attitude is the biggest problem. What does he mean by "Take the mid-term as an exercise?" (although it was indeed a good one as all kinds of questions were covered) For students who had prepared the mid-term for weeks, their efforts became a joke due the negligence of the teaching team. Though I did not get a satisfactory grade in my view in mid-term and I actually took advantage of the grading scheme change, I still felt angry for those who spent a great deal of time and got good grades in mid-term.

AS A WARM REMINDER, DO NOT TAKE ANY COURSE TAUGHT BY HIM IN ON-LINE MODE IF YOU WANT TO HAVE GOOD MOOD AFTER AND BEFORE THE EXAM.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme changed two times. Please refered to other posts for more details.
I think the overall grading is friendly. A range is easy to achieve if you make some effort, but I want to emphasize that it neither REASONABLE nor NORMAL to put 70% weight on a 3-hour final that only has 8 questions. (actually I can say that 100% weight is left on it since the hws allow unlimited attempt) Although for the teaching team, it is easy to distinguish different levels of students, for the students who work hard for the whole semester, they may lose one sub-grade or more due to a careless make caused by anxiety.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very low. Remember to make good use of questions in class-viva as exercise.

reviews.author: runnnorth
reviews.comment_content:
Content of MATH2011:
- 3D space + vector in 3D space
- Dot & cross products
- Lines & planes in 3D space
- Quadric surfaces
- Vector-valued functions + their calculus
- Multivariable functions
- Level curves + limits for multivariable functions
- Different coordinate systems
- Partial derivatives + their chain rule
- Gradient vectors + tangent planes + extreme values
- Double integration + its implications
- Triple integration + its implications
- Vector fields
- Line integrals + line integrals in vector fields
- Green's theorem
- Surface integrals
- Divergence + Stokes' theorems
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Ho's teaching was a bit slow, as he spent a lot of time going through examples from the lecture notes. If you already know some stuff, you might get bored easily. Other than the pacing, he explained all the concepts very clearly. He always provides examples and diagrams to help you visualize/grasp a new concept. If you want to do more practices, then you can always join the weekly tutorial hosted by TAs.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
15% by online homework assignment
10% individual presentation
15% by quiz (pretty much a mid-term)
60% by online final examination

The grading is very good this semester. The homework and the presentation are very straightforward + you have multiple attempts on the homework questions, so try to ace those if possible. As for the quiz and the final, as long as you learn the concepts well and do a lot of practice, you should be good to go.
reviews.comment_workload: Very good level of workload. There are 6 sets (around 7-10 questions) of online homework throughout the semester, the professor will give you around 2 weeks to do each homework set. There are also 2 individual presentations; you will be given a question to solve, and you will have to record a video of yourself explaining the solution.

Everything "5. Level Curves and Level Surfaces" is pretty easy to understand, and if you did some higher level maths in high school or did well in the MATH1000s, it should be a piece of cake. I covered everything before Line Integrals over the summer, so most of the stuff wasn't challenging, but everything after that is pretty hard imo.

The final was really the only proper test we had. The questions were 60% straight forward calculation questions that you should get as long as you remember all the formulas.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Ming is literally a God when it comes to teaching. He isn't super charismatic or anything, but he will make sure to explain everything perfectly. If I hadn't covered the topics myself, I probably would've gone to class. He asks questions to make sure people are more or less engaged with what he's saying. I had him for MATH2111 as well, and he was the reason I did well in that course.

The TA is decent and helpful, but mostly unneeded.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Individual Presentations:
- Presentation 1:
    - Mean: 4.36/5
    - Me: 5/5
- Presentation 2:
    - Mean: 4.59/5
    - Me: 5/5

15% Homework Assignments:
  - 6 WebWorks:
     - Mean: 92.4/100
     - Me: 100/100

15% Quiz:
  - Mean: 12.2/18, SD: 3.6
  - Me: 15/18

60% Final:
- Mean: 23.3/36, SD: 6.2
- Me: 27/36

Overall percentage: 82.5% -> A
I'd say grading was mostly fair and very transparent. Dr Ho told us that the results of the final had a normal distribution so cheating seems to have been unlikely.
reviews.comment_workload:
There were 6 WebWork homeworks, with unlimited attempts for each. Don't expect this to be the case all the time though. They were spread apart pretty well so I never had to spend more than an hour or two per homework. They are pretty simple questions assuming you read the lecture notes or follow everything in class.

This was another online sem so 10% of the grade was actually from individual presentations. Frankly, these are a joke. They are super simple questions that you spend 10 minutes solving (max) and another 10 minutes (max) recording yourself explaining.

Studying recommendations: if you feel like you understand Calculus for the most part, you might as well not study until 75% of the course is over. I highly, highly recommend you use "Einstein Kong's Tutorial Website" for concise lecture notes with practice questions from the textbook and detailed answers for them too. Just google it and you'll find it. They are great for recapping and practicing for the final

reviews.author: fishfillett
reviews.title: requires a lot of time in revising
reviews.comment_content:
multivariable calculus: introduces a lot of new concepts such as conservative vector fields, double and triple integrals, flux integrals, green's and divergence theorem etc.

basically, a new concept would be introduced every 1-2 lectures, so there are a lot of things covered in the final exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
ho hon ming is an interesting lecturer and he explains examples and concepts during lessons in depth. he creates detailed lecture notes and elaborates them during lectures. the only con with his notes was that they were often too lengthy and it was difficult for me to find the equations i need.

however, he loves to send emails and will send up to 7 reminders for homework and quizzes.
reviews.comment_grading:
the distribution of grades are as below:

webwork: 15%
individual presentation: 10% (5% each)
midterm: 15%
final 60%

the grades reflect on how much you spend time on the course. because there are a lot of concepts you have to remember, you have to use a lot of efforts in order to revise. sometimes I would mix up some concepts because some of them are really similar, but as long as you are willing to put the time in it you should be fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
there are 6 homework sets in total which are fairly easy to do and ho hon ming gives us a lot of time (1-2 weeks, around 8-10 questions per homework set) to complete it, so it should not be too difficult.

as for the individual presentations, ho hon ming allows us to submit really short video as long as you fulfilled his requirements and show all steps and an answer. although the limit for the video is 10 minutes, I got full mark in submitting one that is only 3 minutes long.

reviews.author: Lewandowski
reviews.title: The grade reflects how much effort you put in this course
reviews.comment_content:
This course targets at students from engineering school and has more emphasis on the applications of multi-variable calculus in engineering topics. The content covered will be useful for further studies in fluid mechanics, electronics etc.

Topics included:
1. Vectors, dot product, cross product and its applications
2. Lines, Planes and vector applications
3. Cylinders and Surfaces
4. Vector-valued functions (limit, derivatives, integrals, tangent line, arc length and re-parametrizaton, sketching)
5. Function of two variables, domains, range, level curve, continuity, limit
6. Coordinate systems conversion
7. Partial Differentiation, chain rule, implicit differentiation
8. Gradient vectors, directional derivatives and its applications (normal line, tangent plane, equation of tangent line etc)
9. Linear approxiamtion
____________________________________

10. Extreme value and its applications
11. Double integration under general, rectangular region
12. Double integration under polar coordinate system
13. Surface Area and its aoplications
14. Triple Integrals under rectangular and cylindrical coordinate system
15. Line Integrals under vector field
16. Vector fields
17. Conservative vector field (find potential function, Fundamental Theorem of Line Integrals, Path independence)
18. Divergence and Curl
19. Green's Theorem
20. Surface Area and Surface Integrals
21. Flux and Divergence Theorem

(Stoke's Theorem is omitted this semester)

reviews.comment_workload:
Very light. The webwork is very easy to do.
However, as there are many online materials, I strongly suggest you guys to find them and do practice.
For me, I practise by topics. I never
do past papers.

DO NOT suddenly "studying" the answers of thousands of questions in whatever online sources right before one week of the quiz and exam🙃 that's useless to help you "above mean"😏😏

DO practice constantly is the key. Of course I am not asking you guys to do
tonnes of questions per day, but maybe 10-20 will definitely enough to manage the tests but at the same time not "chur-ing"😆

I won't think it is "chur" after all because that's what a student should do: study~😊

If you are a guy who just want to have an ok grade (like me),  then you can take my advice😉.

reviews.comment_grading:
I'm giving E for grading not because of the grading itself but the way they assess students' performance, which I will explain.

HW 10% Midterm 30% Final 60%
or
HW 10% Final 90%

The final exam was changed to an online exam due to class cancellation. However, the paper was only 12 MCs, one of which was a declaration of academic honors. So it was 11 MCs that determined 90% of your grade, is this even reasonable? I'm pretty sure lots of students cheated since it was impossible to catch.

Mean= 7/12, sd=2.55
I got 6 out of 12 correct (HW 95%) and received C+, my friend got 7 out of 12 correct and received B, 8/12 for B+, 9/12 for A-, 10/12 for A. Is this even sensible!?!? I believe others just lucked out, the final "exam" was just a very expensive gamble. Also, pass/fail was not an option, unlike every other course for no reason.

In this semester due to time constraints, Prof. Qian did not teach Green's theorem.
1.1 to 3.1 for the midterm, all topics for final but actually is all content not tested in the midterm so I do not think you would have to worry about content before very much.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Qian's content for this course is comparatively easier than Dr Ho Hon Ming's after reading both of their notes so I recommend taking this course in a semester with Prof. Qian. (unless you actually want to learn more, then take Dr Ho's class). Also, we ran out of time to teach Green's theorem which made the course easier as well. I think he teaches quite well, provides some simple and good examples and the class is not extremely boring. The first few lectures were pretty simple and rather basic content but get exponentially harder later on especially topic 4 and 5. He will do some pretty difficult proofs in class but do not worry about those as this course is purely computational, so just understand the calculations and how to get to the answer (the process is important). Lecture video is also provided so there is no need to really attend lectures.

For tutorials, just a very short tutorial exercise, teaching for tutorials were not great but it is ok. A lot fewer exercises to practice from than teaching staff from MSC. Could skip it as TA's notes are online and he just goes through the exercise. Just use them for practice for exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Homework
30% Midterm (1 hour)
60% Final (2 and a half hours)

Midterm: Mean 73.68/100 SD 25.9
Final: Mean 66.26/100 SD 23.11

Midterm had a lot of students getting full marks and even questions that were in the tutorial notes or in past papers (from Peter Gao) so I suggest practising from those.
The midterm was more straightforward than the final, but I think both of the exams were not extremely difficult, just have to make sure you really understand the content before which is the most difficult part, applying the content to the questions once you understand it is relatively simple.

Exam grades are pretty varied with quite a few getting full marks and quite a few also getting pretty low marks, so either you understand the content or not.

Grading is pretty average, not too bad or not too good, just about fair.
reviews.comment_workload:
12 homework on webwork: the first few were quite easy but gets harder later on. They are actually pretty good practice for exams. If you are a deadline fighter, a lot of the homework later on (especially the integrals) could just be done online as long as you plug in the correct integral and its limits (saves time for computation).

To do well in this course, also make sure you understand at general one-variable calculus and are able to do questions from there well e.g. from 1000 math courses or else you might struggle with the integrals computationally. But I think overall the questions in exams computationally (not conceptionally) should be easier than in math 1000s.

For exams, I suggest just use tutorials for practice. It is pretty sufficient for Prof. Qian's exams which are relatively easy as its nearly all computational questions (one question in final about different surfaces). Understanding the concept is most important as it gets pretty abstract later on, so make sure you read through the lecture notes.
