reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
- Equations of lines and planes in space (shortest distance between (A) and (B) is often asked)
- Space curves
- Limit, continuity, partial derivatives, chain rule, tangent plane, max and min (one of the LQ in final exam)
- Multiple Integrals (Double and Triple Integrals)
- Vector Calculus (Line integral, surface integral, flux, divergence, potential, and the three fundamental theorems that link between concepts of multiple integrals and vector calculus)
(Note: Stokes' Theorem was not tested)

Make sure you are really familiar with differentiation and integration as the course is fundamentally based on them.

Some of the contents taught in tutorial class were out of syllabus. Lecture notes were distributed one by one in every lecture. They contained mainly examples and their detailed computation steps, as well as how to think of the method used.

Lecture videos were uploaded to Canvas.

As the midterm exam only consisted of MCs, it is quite hard for you to get 1 sd above mean to secure an A. One wrong answer can differ a lot. So, be cautious when selecting the choice. Also, as I took the make-up midterm exam, I found it challenging whereas my friends felt easy with their exam. Therefore, even if the professor does not announce any amendment in the difficulty of the make-up exam paper, I suggest you not to try provided that you can have a choice.
reviews.comment_teaching: I am afraid Mr Ho is not patient enough to answer students' questions. Nonetheless, I appreciate his consistency of teaching quality as he taught 3 consecutive sections 2 days a week, and he would like to use the visualizer and to write onto the teaching version of his lecture notes with different colours of pens.

reviews.comment_content:
The content is a bit harder than what we have learned in MATH1014 and requires integration techniques and similar concepts in MATH1014. The contents after midterm are much harder than what I learned before the midterm.

The topics are:
1. Vectors, Dot products  Cross products, Line and curves in space
2. Vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Length of curves
3. Functions of several variables, level curves, limits and continuity of functions of several variables
4. Conversion between cylindrical, rectangular and spherical coordinate systems, partial derivatives, Chain rules.
5. Gradient vectors, Tangent planes  
Tangent planes on the aspect of approximation, Extreme values

After the mditerm:

6. Double integration on rectangular regions, double integration on general regions, polar coordinate system
7. Double integrals in polar coordinate, surface area, triple integrals in rectangular coordinate system.
8. Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system, line integrals, vector fields and line integrals in vector fields
9. Flux of a vector field, path independence, potential functions and conservative vector fields and Green’s theorem in the plane
10. Surface integrals, flux of a vector field across a surface
11. Divergence theorem
reviews.comment_teaching:

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof QIAN did a really good job preparing the notes and lectures. And for some important concepts, he will explain it twice both in Engilsh and Chinese. This is actually quite suprising and may be an advantage for Chinese speakers.
reviews.comment_grading:
I see that many students have posted reviews blaming Prof QIAN fore his grading scheme arrangements especially after what happened in the midterm. I actually have a different point of view, for those who hate and suffered from this kind of arrangement, please accept my sincere sympathy. But I will not blame Prof QIAN for this eventual arrangement as personnaly I think this is already the best arrangement after what happened in the midterm.

1. The Prof doesn't hope for the technical issues during the midterm either. he tried his best to arrange a midterm under such a difficult period, and he was willing to hear from students' different advice after what happened, at least we have nothing to blame for his attitude.
2. Some may think that voiding the midterm and "taking it as a good exercise" is irresponsible. But the fact is that, the influence of the technical issue in the midterm is high enough to affect a lot more than the students who didn't have their answers recorded. Firstly, during the last 15 min of the exam , the whole proctoring zoom meeting is filled with noise about students and professors discussing about the technincal issues, for an exam that requires you to finish 30 questions in 1 hour, I don't need to tell you how tight is the time and how annoying it is to hear all that noise in the last 15 mins of the exam. So the noise effect is one thing. What's more is that many students who have score recorded didn't get their real score recorded. Like if he/she submitted once at 20 min, then he/she didn't preview and submitted again at last, the second time the answers will not be recorded and he/she can only receive points for the first 20min answering period. So even with a "recorded score", as 80% of the students did, the recorded score may not be the real deserved score.
3. Many blamed that all the efforts studying for the midterm become a waste due to the arrangements. But isn't it our duty as a student to understand the contents of courses as best as we can? the studying for the midterm will be helpful for the final as well and certainly helful for understanding the whole course.

Now to the eventual grading scheme. 30%HW+70%Final, this is already better than math1014 which has 75%final. So I am satisfied enough with his arrangements. He couldn't have done much better. But I do hope Prof Qian can learn a lesson from the midterm techinal issues and make this a even better course in the future. For those who took advantage from this arrangement change, Congratulations! For those who suffered loss, please accept my sincere sympathy but let's not blame the prof too much of this. He already tried to make it as fair as possible.

reviews.author: I Want 1st Hon!
reviews.title: Important Course for SOME majors (e.g. CIVL, MECH, AE, CENG...)
reviews.comment_content:
Grading depends on students' performance, NOT Absolute grading.
In exams, no calculator allowed, closed book.

Lecture (Topics):
1-3. Vectors, Dot products, Cross products
4. Line and curves in space
5-6. Vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Length of curves
7. Functions of several variables, Level curves
8. Limits and continuity of functions of several variables
9. Conversion between cylindrical, rectangular and spherical coordinate systems
10. Partial derivatives, Chain rules.
11. Gradient vectors
12. Tangent planes + 2 examples from Lecture 13 (Tangent plane)  

Midterm: for all above lectures & topics (they emphasis on the shortest distance of planes & parametrization the most!)
-------------
13. (NOT IN EXAM) Linear approximation, differentials (skipped, probably because of NO Calculator!)
14. Extreme values
15-16. Double integration on rectangular regions, Double integration on general regions, Polar coordinate system Review
17-18. Double integrals in polar coordinate, Surface area, Triple integrals in rectangular coordinate system.
19. Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system
20. Line integrals, Vector fields
21. Flux of a vector field, Path independence, Potential functions, Conservative vector fields
22. Green’s theorem in the plane
23. Surface integrals, Flux of a vector field across a surface
24. Divergence theorem (P.S. Stokes’ Theorem is skipped)

Final: CUMULATIVE from Lecture 1-24, (they still emphasis on the shortest distance of planes & parametrization before midterms in some MC Questions, and literally ALL are approximately equal importance for the lectures after midterm)
-------------
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture Video at home! I skipped most of the lectures (about two-thirds skipped). I always speed up his teaching (1.5x or 2x faster). He speaks normal in pace but like a robot...

P.S. The video recording (in 1 of the lectures) has a problem (No sound recorded); AND he posts the video approximately 1-2 weeks after.

Notes are not updated, 12 practice exercises in canvas which is only for L1-L14 (since he said he had no time to do that). His overall teaching is good, but he sometimes asks questions which a primary students can easily answer (e.g. what is line integral of 0, what is surface integral of 0). HHM sends us A LOT OF reminders, and some tips for exams.

In the past, I know HHM teaches most of the students. However, there are 5 sessions (3 instructors) this year teaching this course. I heard one of the instructor has completed ALL and extra stuff for this course (e.g. Stokes' Theorem & Lagrange Multiplier). However, HHM has been teaching in an extremely similar way compared with his previous years' teaching.

P.S. We had lectures in LT-J and many students sleep because of the atmosphere and the "sleeping bed".

For tutorial,
Tommy teaches OK. You could understand his Hong Kong English. Besides, he makes me feel that he just wants to finish everything. He printed out Einstein Kong's tutorial notes, and he taught by using some of the examples.
reviews.comment_grading:

(15 MC, 75 mins exam)
Mean (28.35/45); SD (8)
I got 36/45, i.e. 12 MC correct.

(13 MC, 4 LQs (Absolute Minima & Maxima, Surface Integrals to find area, Reversing Order of Triple Integrals, Divergence Theorem))
Mean (46.15/90); SD (17.8)
I got 63/90 (27/39+36/51 for MC & LQ respectively);

6 Webworks (10%): Full marks
Overall: 76/100, Grade: B+

6 Webworks which is neither hard nor easy. Professor usually releases the webworks approximately 3 weeks once, each release has 2 webworks to do. They extend the deadline ONLY for the last two webworks, probably these are difficult!

if you go through the lengthy and "words"thy lecture notes. I personal think the explanation of the examples given in the lecture notes has too much words in it, and this makes the revision become harder for ME (maybe some of you like explanation more).

reviews.author: Sze Sze
reviews.title: Clear and organized instruction and lecture notes
reviews.comment_content: The content is very organized and easy to understand, especially since the professor's lecture notes cover nearly 100% of the course's content, utilize colorful diagrams and contain detailed descriptions.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is very clear and organized. The professor clearly understands what he is teaching, and is able to answer questions posed by students in the zoom chat room. My biggest issue is that his teaching progress is a big slow at times, especially at the beginning when he just covers basic concepts from high school or year one. However, as the notes are so clear, you can definitely read and study ahead outside class.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair and based on many different components including a midterm exam, final exam, homework and presentations. Therefore, as long as you complete most of the work in time, you do not have to worry that much about your exam condition.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is decent. For work outside lectures, there are weekly homework questions and two presentations (in total, in the entire semester). Each presentation usually contains one math question, where the professor requires you to film a short video explaining how you completed the question, using calculations and diagrams. The homework and presentation questions are usually quite similar to the examples given in lectures, even though some of the homework questions for later chapters do require more thinking.

reviews.comment_content:
Week 1: Three Dimensional space, Vectors in the plane, Vectors in three dimensions, Dot products
Week 2: More examples on vectors and dot products, Cross products, Lines and planes in 3 space
Week 3: More examples on lines and planes, cylinders and quadric surfaces, Calculus I of vector-valued functions, Motion in space, Calculus II of vector-valued functions, Length of curves
Week 4: More examples on vector functions, functions of several variables, level curves, limits and continuity of functions of several variables
Week 5: Conversion between cylindrical, rectangular and spherical coordinate systems, partial derivatives, Chain rules
Week 6: Gradient vectors, Tangent planes
-----------------------Quiz-----------------------------
Week 7: Tangent planes on the aspect of approximation, Extreme values, More examples on gradient vectors
Week 8: Double integration on rectangular regions, double integration on general regions, polar coordinate system
Week 9: Double integrals in polar coordinate, surface area, triple integrals in rectangular coordinate system
Week 10: Triple integrals in cylindrical coordinate system, line integrals, vector fields and line integrals in vector fields
